author: Special Correspondent
text:
While senior leaders had expressed their displeasure at a decentralised mode of interviews involving persons with lack of electoral experience, the aspirants who attended the process on Wednesday welcomed the new arrangement, stating that they would have more chances of getting a party ticket for the Assembly election as the district presidents concerned were on the interview panel.

On Wednesday, over 250 ticket aspirants attended the interview for the Chennai region at Satyamurthy Bhavan with close to a third being women. Many had put in decades in the party. The interview panel was led by veteran leader D. Yasoda and also comprised Congress national spokesperson and actor Khushbu.

The interaction was kept simple. Every aspirant had to answer a set of eight questions, including one on the percentage of minority population in the constituency for which they were seeking ticket. The financial strength of the person was also ascertained.

Ms. Yasoda posed questions that tested the aspirant’s knowledge of the particular area and issues involved.

Till 2011, a high-level election committee did the interviews.

Ms. Yasoda said the process helps to filter those who remain inactive all through but try to show themselves as hard workers just before the elections. Interviews were conducted simultaneously in all 32 districts.

However, the process did not go without controversy. Some leaders belonging to factions of former Union Ministers P. Chidambaram and K.V. Thangkabalu kept away.
title: Congress’ new approach cheers ticket aspirants
